case_name: Bombay Port Trust Employees Union v. Trustees of the Port of Bombay

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 325 of 1965 was filed.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 325 of 1965.

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from the Award dated September 20, 1963 of the Central Government Industrial Tribunal, Bombay in Reference CG IT-25 of 1962.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the Award dated September 20, 1963 of the Central Government Industrial Tribunal, Bombay in Reference CG IT-25 of 1962.

facts.text: Appellants are the workmen of the Bombay Port Trust, represented by the Bombay Port Trust Employees Union.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants are the workmen of the Bombay Port Trust, who are and have been represented in this dispute by the Bombay Port Trust Employees Union.

facts.text: Respondents are the trustees of the Port of Bombay.

anchor.surface_text: The respondents to this appeal are the trustees of the Port of Bombay.

facts.text: Reference made by the Government of India under s. 10(2) of the Industrial Disputes Act, 1947 on a joint application of the parties.

anchor.surface_text: This is an appeal by special leave against an award dated September 20, 1963 made by the Presiding Officer of the Central Government Industrial Tribunal, Bombay in a reference made by the Government of India under s. 10

facts.text: Matter in dispute: Whether the existing system of work of the shore crew of the Princes and Victoria Docks under which each shift consists of 8 hours normal duty, 2 hours variable recess and 2 hours overtime needs any modification.

anchor.surface_text: The reference was made on a joint application of the parties. and the matter in dispute was stated to be Whether the existing system of work of the shore crew of the Princes and Victoria Docks under which each shift companysists of 8 hours numbermal duty, 2 hours variable recess and 12 hours overtime needs any modification?

facts.text: Tribunal held that the Union was not able to establish that the existing system of work needed any modification.

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal, by the award impugned here, held that the Union was number able to establish that the existing system of work needed any modification.

facts.text: Trustees introduced a two shift system of work in the Alexandra Docks on June 30, 1953.

anchor.surface_text: From the facts appearing on the record it appears that the Trustees first introduced a two shift system of work in the Alexandra Docks on June 30, 1953

facts.text: Two shift system extended to the Princes and Victoria Docks on December 15, 1953.

anchor.surface_text: and the same system was extended to the Princes and Victoria Docks on December 15, 1953.

facts.text: Previously, the shore crew at all these places worked in a single shift and were liable to be called out at any hour.

anchor.surface_text: Previously, the shore crew at all these places worked in a single shift and were liable to be called out at any hour of the day or night.

facts.text: When the two shift system began, each shift of 12 hours was broken up into 8 hours duty, 2 hours variable recess and 2 hours overtime.

anchor.surface_text: When the two shift system began, each shift of 12 hours was broken up into 8 hours duty, 2 hours variable recess and 2 hours overtime. The hours of rest were kept variable as they depended on the tides.

facts.text: In 1956 the workmen, represented by the Port Trust General Workers Union, made a demand for a fixed recess of two hours.

anchor.surface_text: In 1956 the workmen, who were then represented by the Port Trust General Workers Union, made a demand for a fixed recess of two hours.

facts.text: Trustees rejected the demand for fixed recess and threatened to introduce a three-shift system.

anchor.surface_text: The Trustees apprehended that this was a device to get 4 hours overtime and rejected the demand. The General Workers Union was informed that if the demand was pressed a three-shift system would be introduced.

facts.text: Workmen accepted 2 hours variable recess as near the middle of the shift as possible.

anchor.surface_text: The workmen then retraced their steps and accepted a 2 hours variable recess but requested that it should be as near the middle of the shift as possible.

facts.text: Port Trust gave notice under s. 9A of the Industrial Disputes Act on June 25, 1960 announcing introduction of variable recess at Alexandra Docks.

anchor.surface_text: The workmen at the Alexandra Docks seemed to have accepted a variable recess of two hours but the Port Trust gave a numberice under s. 9A of the Industrial Disputes Act on June 25, 1960 announcing the introduction of variable recess

facts.text: At Alexandra Docks, shore crew work 8 hours duty, 1 hour variable recess, 3 hours overtime.

anchor.surface_text: The Trustees, therefore, resolved that the shore crew at the Alexandra Docks should work for 8 hours and that there should be a variable recess of one hour and overtime of three hours should be paid.

facts.text: At Princes and Victoria Docks and Butcher Island, 8 hours duty, 2 hours variable rest, 2 hours overtime.

anchor.surface_text: Thus the 12 hours shift at the Alexandra Docks was 8 hours of duty, 3 hours overtime and one hour variable recess. This system was, however, number extended to the princes and Victoria Docks and Butcher Island.

facts.text: Union contended that the division of 12 hours shift into 8 hours work, 2 hours rest and 2 hours overtime violated the Minimum Wages Act.

anchor.surface_text: The Union companytended that this division of 12 hours shift into 8 hours work, 2 hours rest and 2 hours overtime violated the provisions of the Minimum Wages Act and that the so-called period of rest was illusory

facts.text: Union claimed 12 hours shift should be 8 hours work and 4 hours overtime like Flotilla Crew.

anchor.surface_text: The Union claimed that a 12 hours shift should be divided into 8 hours work and 4 hours overtime as was the case with the Flotilla Crew.

facts.text: Trustees contended no breach of Minimum Wages Act and work loads differ.

anchor.surface_text: This claim was opposed by the Trustees. According to them, there was numberbreach of the provisions of the Minimum Wages Act. They companytended that, regard being had to the number of actual work hours,

facts.text: Tribunal accepted the entire case of the Trustees.

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal accepted the entire case put forward on behalf of the Trustees and the Union has appealed to this Court.

facts.text: Alexandra Docks work on lock gates system regulating water depth artificially; Princes and Victoria Docks are tidal.

anchor.surface_text: In explanation of this difference it may be pointed out that the Alexandra Docks work on a system of lock gates which enables the depth of water at the docks to be artificially regulated but the Princes and Victoria Docks, being tidal, work only at high tide.

facts.text: Flotilla Crew has 12 hours duty with 8 hours work and 4 hours overtime.

anchor.surface_text: The Flotilla Crew has to remain on duty for full 12 hours and they work as and when they are required. Although their hours of duty are only 8 they are entitled, if present for work, for overtime up to four hours.

facts.text: Supreme Court holds that the Tribunal's decision is right and appeal fails.

anchor.surface_text: We hold, therefore, that the decision of the Central Government Industrial Tribunal is right in a circumstances of this case. The appeal must therefore fail.

facts.text: Workmen at Princes and Victoria Docks informed each day of rest period for following day.

anchor.surface_text: Under this arrangement the shore crew working at the Princes and Victoria Docks were informed each day what the period of rest would be on the following day.

anchor.surface_text: The sections are Nos. 13 and 14 and the rules Nos. 24 and 25. The whole of the matter in dispute admittedly is governed by these, four provisions.

concepts.interpretation: Authorises fixing number of hours for normal working day inclusive of specified intervals of rest; normal working day includes hours of actual duty and specified intervals; intervals are breaks where worker not required to work or attend.

concepts.interpretation: Overtime payable for work in excess of normal working day (9 hours); double rate for excess hours of actual work.

concepts.interpretation: Double ordinary rate for overtime over 9 hours/day or 48 hours/week; weekly limit ensures average 8 hours/day at ordinary rate.

issues.text: Whether the existing system of work of the shore crew of the Princes and Victoria Docks under which each shift companysists of 8 hours numbermal duty, 2 hours variable recess and 12 hours overtime needs any modification?

anchor.surface_text: Whether the existing system of work of the shore crew of the Princes and Victoria Docks under which each shift companysists of 8 hours numbermal duty, 2 hours variable recess and 12 hours overtime needs any modification?

issues.text: whether the fixing of a two hours rest and two hours overtime involves a breach of the two sections of the Act and the two rules quoted here

anchor.surface_text: The controversy in the present case is a narrow one. It is whether the fixing of a two hours rest and two hours overtime involves a breach of the two sections of the Act and the two rules quoted here ?

issues.text: whether the system of variable recess does number satisfy the requirements of rest which is the basis for fixing statutorily the hours of work in relation to wages

anchor.surface_text: On behalf of the Union the learned Solicitor General has argued the case almost entirely from the legal stand- point and has attempted to establish that the break-up of a 12 hours shift into 8 hours duty, 2 hours rest and 2 hours overtime offends the Minimum Wages Act. He, has in addition submitted that the system of variable recess does number satisfy the requirements of rest which is the basis for fixing statutorily the hours of work in relation to wages.

issues.text: Whether the 9 hours constituting a numbermal working day under Rule 24 include one or more intervals of rest

arguments.claim: The division of 12 hours shift into 8 hours work, 2 hours rest and 2 hours overtime violated the provisions of the Minimum Wages Act and the period of rest was illusory

anchor.surface_text: The Union contended that this division of 12 hours shift into 8 hours work, 2 hours rest and 2 hours overtime violated the provisions of the Minimum Wages Act and that the so-called period of rest was illusory since, being variable, it was some times given right at the commencement of the shift and some times at the end, depending on the tides or the exigencies of the work.

arguments.court_reasoning: Normal working day is 9 hours of work plus specified rest intervals spread over up to 12 hours; variable recess valid if specified in advance

arguments.claim: Section 13 authorises fixing number of hours for normal working day inclusive of specified intervals of rest; normal working day includes hours of actual duty and specified intervals

anchor.surface_text: Section 13 only authorises Government to fix the number of hours which shall constitute a normal working day, inclusive of one,-. or more specified intervals. The normal working day thus includes (a) hours of actual duty, and (b) one or more specified intervals.

arguments.claim: Interval of rest means a break during which workman on duty but not called to display physical activity or sustained attention; must be specified beforehand

anchor.surface_text: By interval under s. 13 is obviously meant interval of rest... It means a break in the work during which a workman, though present on duty, is not called upon to display either physical activity or sustained attention.

arguments.claim: Rule 24 prescribes 9 hours of work for normal working day; working day inclusive of rest not to spread over more than 12 hours

anchor.surface_text: Rule 24 which prescribes the number of hours of work which is to constitute a normal working day. Sub-rule (1) (a) provides that the number of hours constituting a normal working day for an adult shall be 9. As the heading of the Rule shows these are the hours of work.

arguments.claim: Overtime payable for actual work in excess of 9 hours per day at double rate

anchor.surface_text: Overtime is payable for work in excess of the number of hours constituting a normal working day. From s. 13 read with Rule 24 we know that the number of hours constituting a normal working day is 9... at the overtime rate... double the ordinary rate of wages.

arguments.claim: Variable recess does not violate MW Act if specified in advance
Cases of different crews not comparable due to differences in work nature

anchor.surface_text: The crew at the Princes and Victoria Docks work in a different way and their case cannot be compared with that of the Flotilla Crew or the crew at the Alexandra Docks.

arguments.claim: MW Act lacks compulsory breaks like Factories Act s.55 due to nature of some employments

holdings.text: The decision of the Central Government Industrial Tribunal is right in the circumstances of this case and the appeal fails.

anchor.surface_text: We hold, therefore, that the decision of the Central Government Industrial Tribunal is right in a circumstances of this case. The appeal must therefore fail.

holdings.reasoning_summary: System complies with ss.13,14 Minimum Wages Act and Rules 24,25; union failed to prove need for modification; work nature justifies differences from other crews.

holdings.text: The fixing of two hours rest and two hours overtime does not involve a breach of ss.13,14 of the Minimum Wages Act and Rules 24,25.

anchor.surface_text: The controversy in the present case is a narrow one. It is whether the fixing of a two hours rest and two hours overtime involves a breach of the two sections of the Act and the two rules quoted here ?

holdings.reasoning_summary: Normal working day is 9 hours actual work + specified rest intervals spread over <=12 hours; overtime only for excess actual work; 8+2+2 fits within limits.

holdings.text: Variable recess satisfies requirements of rest under the Minimum Wages Act if specified in advance.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Interval of rest is pre-specified break during duty without physical activity or attention; tidal work necessitates variability; advance notice given daily.

holdings.text: The 9 hours of a normal working day under Rule 24 are hours of work and do not include intervals of rest.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual reading distinguishes 'hours of work' (9) from rest intervals; 'inclusive' governs spread-over limit of 12 hours, not work hours.

holdings.text: Interval of rest under s.13 is a specified break during which workman is on duty but not called upon to display physical activity or sustained attention.

anchor.surface_text: By interval under s. 13 is obviously meant interval of rest... It means a break in the work during which a workman, though present on duty, is not called upon to display either physical activity or sustained attention.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Derived from s.13(2)(c) and s.13(3); distinguishes from periods of inaction due to lack of work counted as actual duty.

holdings.text: Cases of shore crew at Princes/Victoria Docks cannot be compared with Alexandra Docks or Flotilla Crew for parity in overtime/rest due to differing work nature.

anchor.surface_text: The crew at the Princes and Victoria Docks work in a different way and their case cannot be compared with that of the Flotilla Crew or the crew at the Alexandra Docks.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Tidal docks vs lock gates vs flotilla duties; actual workloads differ; no parallel for equal treatment.

holdings.text: Minimum Wages Act lacks compulsory breaks after 5 hours like Factories Act s.55 due to nature of certain employments.
holdings.reasoning_summary: MW Act flexible for tidal/variable work; contrasts with Factories Act's rigid intervals.

justification_sets.label: Rule 24 Minimum Wages Central Rules 1950 support

anchor.surface_text: We hold, therefore, that the decision of the Central Government Industrial Tribunal is right in a circumstances of this case. The appeal must therefore fail.

outcome.relief_summary: Appeal fails; decision of the Central Government Industrial Tribunal upheld, no modification to the existing system of work needed
